sn3.4:1.2: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,
sn3.4:1.3: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.
sn3.4:1.4: ‘Who are those who love themselves? And who are those who don’t love themselves?’
sn3.4:1.6: ‘Those who do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind
sn3.4:1.11: It’s because they treat themselves like an enemy.
sn3.4:1.12: That’s why they don’t love themselves.
sn3.4:1.13: Those who do good things by way of body, speech, and mind
sn3.4:1.16: “I don’t love myself”, they do really.
sn3.4:1.18: It’s because they treat themselves like a loved one.
sn3.4:1.19: That’s why they do love themselves.’”
sn3.4:2.1: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!” said the Buddha. And he repeated the king’s statement, adding:
sn3.4:3.2: you’d not yoke yourself to wickedness.
sn3.4:3.3: For happiness is not easy to find
sn3.4:3.4: by someone who does bad deeds.
sn3.4:4.1: When you’re seized by the terminator
sn3.4:4.2: as you give up your human life,
sn3.4:4.3: what can you call your own?
sn3.4:4.4: What do you take when you go?
sn3.4:4.6: like a shadow that never leaves?
sn3.4:5.1: Both the good and the bad
sn3.4:5.2: that a mortal does in this life
sn3.4:5.3: is what they can call their own.
sn3.4:5.4: That’s what they take when they go.
sn3.4:5.6: like a shadow that never leaves.
sn3.4:6.1: That’s why you should do good,
sn3.4:6.3: The good deeds of sentient beings
sn3.4:6.4: support them in the next world.”
